body:
The big theme is improved editor/IDE support, with dependency "Jack-In" now supported by Clojurephant (will be working on sending PRs to Cider and Calva to take advantage of this). Also some cleanup of issues that caused problems in Intellij/Cursive and Eclipse.

Clojurephant projects can now take advantage of Gradle's toolchain feature to set the JVM used by tasks:

```groovy
java {
  toolchain {
    languageVersion = JavaLanguageVersion.of(17)
  }
}
```

Otherwise, trying to get up-to-date with the latest Gradle versions and best practices, including support for Gradle's configuration cache.

This release also prepares for the [clojurephant-tooling](https://github.com/clojurephant/clojurephant-tooling) library which will be useful in the REPL, in particular for starting ClojureScript REPLs.

## Breaking Changes

- Requires Gradle 6.4+ (drops support for Gradle 5)
- Implementation of `clojure {}` and `clojurescript {}` extensions changed to take advantage of Gradle decorating the types for DSL use. Our tests projects didn't require changes, but we don't have full coverage, so you could encounter some issues with mismatched property types.
- Removed `ClojureBuild.getSourceSet()` and `ClojureScriptBuild.getSourceSet()` due to incompatibility with Gradle's configuration cache #169 
- Java test classes not on dev classpath (by default) #173 

## Enhancements

- Supports injecting dependencies into the nrepl classpath via `-Pdev.clojurephant.jack-in.nrepl=dep1,dep2` (where `dep*` are the typical Gradle `group:artifact:version` notation) #179 
- `clojureRepl` classpath is now enriched with sources/javadoc JARs of your dependencies (useful in CIDER).
- Cleaner support (and documentation) for having Java code depend on Clojure code ([see FAQ](https://clojurephant.dev/clojurephant/main/faq.html#_how_do_i_build_java_code_that_depends_on_clojure_code)) #173 
- `clojureRepl` depends on fewer other tasks, meaning it should start up a smidge faster #173 
 #174 
- Allow Clojure tasks to use Java toolchains
- Support Gradle's configuration cache #169 
- Updates default nrepl version to 0.9.0
- Updates templates to use Gradle 7.5
- Exposing Clojure and ClojureScript configuration via the Tooling API #188 

## Fixes

- Improves experience (slightly) for tasks that use prepl (it will fail faster if the Clojure runtime fails to start) also it extends the timeout before it abandons startup to 30 seconds for larger projects (hopefully fixes #161)
- Fixes a number of deprecation warnings on Gradle 6 and 7
- Handled `AsynchronousCloseExceptions` that could be triggered when any of the Clojure related tasks shut down #173 
- Fixed duplicate source dirs in Eclipse config #127 
- Fixed source root detection in Intellij #160, #108, #66 
- Fixed REPL classpath to include both Clojure and ClojureScript sources #188

## Deprecations

_None_

## Compatibility

Tested on the following version:

<!-- We should indicate Clojure version compatibility at some point, but we don't have tests for this yet -->

| Java Version | Gradle Versions     |
|--------------|---------------------|
| 8             | 6.4.1, 6.9.2, 7.0.2, 7.5.1 |
| 11           | 6.4.1, 6.9.2, 7.0.2, 7.5.1 |
| 17           | 7.3.3, 7.5.1 |

Largely trying to get up-to-date with the latest Gradle versions and best practices, including support for Gradle's configuration cache. Also fixed a number of issues with usage of Clojurephant with Intellij/Cursive and Eclipse.

## Breaking Changes

- Requires Gradle 6.4+ (drops support for Gradle 5)
- Implementation of `clojure {}` and `clojurescript {}` extensions changed to take advantage of Gradle decorating the types for DSL use. Our tests projects didn't require changes, but we don't have full coverage, so you could encounter some issues with mismatched property types.
- Include `dev` source set's compiled ClojureScript on the nREPL classpath (part of our replacement for Figwheel support) #167 
- Removed `ClojureBuild.getSourceSet()` and `ClojureScriptBuild.getSourceSet()` due to incompatibility with Gradle's configuration cache #169 
- Java test classes not on dev classpath (by default) #173 

## Enhancements

- Updates default nrepl version to 0.9.0
- Updates templates to use Gradle 7.5
- Support Gradle's configuration cache #169 
- Cleaner support (and documentation) for having Java code depend on Clojure code ([see FAQ](https://clojurephant.dev/clojurephant/main/faq.html#_how_do_i_build_java_code_that_depends_on_clojure_code)) #173 
- `clojureRepl` depends on fewer other tasks, meaning it should start up a smidge faster #173 

## Fixes

- Improves experience (slightly) for tasks that use prepl (it will fail faster if the Clojure runtime fails to start) also it extends the timeout before it abandons startup to 30 seconds for larger projects (hopefully fixes #161)
- Fixes a number of deprecation warnings on Gradle 6 and 7
- Handled `AsynchronousCloseExceptions` that could be triggered when any of the Clojure related tasks shut down #173 
- Fixed duplicate source dirs in Eclipse config #127 
- Fixed source root detection in Intellij #160, #108, #66 

## Deprecations

_None_

Highlights are better multi-project support, nREPL support, and Java 15 compatibility. Built-in Figwheel support was dropped as part of the nREPL updates that caused complications with the old Figwheel approach. I expect to replace it with a cleaner integration, but it's non-trivial so it was easier to drop it for now.

JUnit integration for `clojure.test` has also changed to use JUnit Platform (via [jovial](https://github.com/ajoberstar/jovial)) instead of JUnit 4, which provides a cleaner API. The documentation has been updated with examples, so please review this before upgrading.

## Breaking Changes

- Requires Clojure 1.10+ (due to use of prepl)
- The old Figwheel support was dropped (for now).
- `clojure.test` integration now requires [jovial](https://github.com/ajoberstar/jovial) and use of the JUnit Platform. See documentation for examples.

## Enhancements

- `clojurephant-tools` JAR has been removed (#155), which avoids the requirement to use Clojars and avoids an issue where the JAR would get included in your runtime dependencies (#147)
- Java 15 is confirmed to be supported
- nREPL 0.8.3 is now included by default
- `.nrepl-port` is now created (by virtue of using nrepl.main instead of our old launcher) #138 

## Fixes

- When not using AOT, sources are now on the classpath of downstream Gradle projects (#134 and #128)
- Resolve a deprecation warning caused by the runtimeClasspath configuration #136 
- NullPointerException during compile fixed #148 (Thanks @jvia)

## Deprecations

_None_

This release is just a small step on the way to 0.6.0. Since we got a few fixes together, this is meant to get them into people's hands while work on the rest of 0.6.0 continues.

Highlights are better multi-project support, nREPL support, and Java 14 compatibility. Built-in Figwheel support was dropped as part of the nREPL updates that caused complications with the old Figwheel approach. I expect to replace it with a cleaner integration, but it's non-trivial so it was easier to drop it for now.

## Breaking Changes

- The old Figwheel support was dropped (for now).

## Enhancements

- Java 14 is confirmed to be supported
- nREPL 0.6.0 is now included by default
- `.nrepl-port` is now created (by virtue of using nrepl.main instead of our old launcher) #138 

## Fixes

- When not using AOT, sources are now on the classpath of downstream Gradle projects (#134 and #128)
- Resolve a deprecation warning caused by the runtimeClasspath configuration #136

The headline feature is ClojureScript compilation support and Figwheel Main! Just apply the `gradle-clojure.clojurescript` plugin and [start configuring](https://gradle-clojure.github.io/gradle-clojure/) (look at the section on the `clojurescript` plugin).

There are also a bunch of features to provide more mature Clojure development, such as initial CIDER support.

Additionally, there are now project templates for basic CLJ app and lib projects and a CLJS app. Check the Quick Start in the README for details.

## Breaking Changes

- Compiler and reflection configuration should be done via the `clojure { builds { ... } }` extension instead of directly on the tasks. See the documentation for details.
- `ClojureCompile.options.aotCompile` and `ClojureCompile.options.copySourceSetToOutput` have been removed. `ClojureCompile` always does AOT compilation. `ClojureCheck` never does AOT compile.
- `ClojureExec` task has been removed. Users should be able to use `JavaExec` pretty trivially to call Clojure code.

## Enhancements

- #28 ClojureScript compilation support
- #29 Figwheel support
- #69  and #96 Project templates (for Clojure app and lib projects, and ClojureScript app projects)
- #35 and #90 `ClojureCheck` task added to support verifying compilation without generating AOT classes.
- #60 Allow custom nREPL middleware or handlers to be provided for the `ClojureNRepl` task (allows use of CIDER)
- #59 Customizable logging from Clojure workers/processes
- #68 Publish tools JAR to Clojars as an alternative to JCenter
- #75 `ClojureNRepl` task now supports a `--port` option to specify a port from the CLI.
- #77 Uberjar documentation added (leverages the Gradle [shadow plugin](http://imperceptiblethoughts.com/shadow/))
- #83 We've upgrade to `nrepl:nrepl:0.3.1` which is the new nREPL project now that it's moved out of Clojure Contrib.
- #8 The last uses of Gradle's conventionMapping have been replaced with Property/Provider.

## Fixes

- #63 Allow compile options to be set via a Groovy Closure.
- #64 Remove duplicate `ERROR` in reflection warning output.
- #72 Improve error message if Clojure isn't on the classpath
- #65 Put compiled Java classes on the classpath of the REPL
- Workers are not used anymore to execute Clojure processes. They seemed to cause a lot of weird state issues.

## Deprecations

_None_

- `ClojureExec` task has been removed. Users should be able to use `JavaExec` pretty trivially to call Clojure code.

## Enhancements

- #28 ClojureScript compilation support
- #29 Figwheel support
- #69  and #96 Project templates (for Clojure app and lib projects, and ClojureScript app projects)
- #35 and #90 `ClojureCheck` task added to support verifying compilation without generating AOT classes.
- #60 Allow custom nREPL middleware or handlers to be provided for the `ClojureNRepl` task (allows use of CIDER)
- #59 Customizable logging from Clojure workers/processes
- #68 Publish tools JAR to Clojars as an alternative to JCenter
- #75 `ClojureNRepl` task now supports a `--port` option to specify a port from the CLI.
- #77 Uberjar documentation added (leverages the Gradle [shadow plugin](http://imperceptiblethoughts.com/shadow/))
- #83 We've upgrade to `nrepl:nrepl:0.3.1` which is the new nREPL project now that it's moved out of Clojure Contrib.
- #8 The last uses of Gradle's conventionMapping have been replaced with Property/Provider.

## Fixes

- #63 Allow compile options to be set via a Groovy Closure.
- #64 Remove duplicate `ERROR` in reflection warning output.
- #72 Improve error message if Clojure isn't on the classpath
- #65 Put compiled Java classes on the classpath of the REPL
- Workers are not used anymore to execute Clojure processes. They seemed to cause a lot of weird state issues.

This release adds REPL support and leverages Gradle's `Test` task to run clojure.test.

## Breaking Changes

- The `clojureTest` (`ClojureTest`) task has been removed, in favor of leveraging the Gradle `Test` task (see #31).

## Enhancements

- #31 clojure.test support is now provided via the default Gradle `Test` task allowing for test filtering and logging customizations
- #33 A `dev` source set is added by default
- #27 REPL support is added via `clojureRepl` (`ClojureNRepl`)
- #36 Resources are now on the classpath during Clojure compilation
- #40 Compiled Java classes are now on the classpath during Clojure compilation (within the same source set)

This release is mostly a refactoring to update the plugin to recent Gradle conventions.

## Breaking Changes

- #12 `ClojureCompile` now has an `options` property that contains the settings like `aotCompile`. This provides consistency with other JVM compile tasks, but will break any existing builds modifying those settings.

## Enhancements

- #23 Annotate all inputs and outputs on `ClojureCompile` and `ClojureTest` to make these tasks fully participate in incremental build (this is different than incremental compilation, #16)
- #9 `ClojureCompile` and `ClojureTest` now use the worker API to kick off Clojure, which on repeated builds will improve the speed of the tasks (by reusing a warm JVM, and often a warm Clojure runtime).
- #11 Adds a `gradle-clojure.clojure-base` plugin that handles adding Clojure source and compilation support to all source sets in the build. The `gradle-clojure.clojure` plugin includes the opinionated `java` plugin and adds a `ClojureTest` task.

## Fixes

_None_

## Deprecations

_None_

## Compatibility

**Java:** requires 8 or higher
**Gradle:** tested against 4.1, 4.2, 4.2.1, 4.3-rc-1
